messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 50 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Deterministic PRAM Approximate Shortest Paths in Polylogarithmic Time and Slightly Super-Linear Work

Paper Abstract: We study a (1+ϵ)1italic-ϵ(1+\epsilon)-approximate single-source shortest paths (henceforth, (1+ϵ)1italic-ϵ(1+\epsilon)-SSSP) in n𝑛n-vertex undirected, weighted graphs in the parallel (PRAM) model of computation. A randomized algorithm with polylogarithmic time and slightly super-linear work O~​(|E|⋅nρ)~𝑂⋅𝐸superscript𝑛𝜌\tilde{O}(|E|\cdot n^{\rho}), for an arbitrarily small ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0, was given by Cohen [Coh94] more than 252525 years ago. Exciting progress on this problem was achieved in recent years [EN17b, EN19, Li19, ASZ19], culminating in randomized polylogarithmic time and O~​(|E|)~𝑂𝐸\tilde{O}(|E|) work. However, the question of whether there exists a deterministic counterpart of Cohen’s algorithm remained wide open. In the current paper we devise the first deterministic polylogarithmic-time algorithm for this fundamental problem, with work O~​(|E|⋅nρ)~𝑂⋅𝐸superscript𝑛𝜌\tilde{O}(|E|\cdot n^{\rho}), for an arbitrarily small ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0. This result is based on the first efficient deterministic parallel algorithm for building hopsets, which we devise in this paper.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 50 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 50"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "A hierarchy of lower bounds for sublinear additive spanners",
        "Simple construction of almost k-wise independent random variables",
        "Network decomposition and locality in distributed computation",
        "On the exponent of the all pairs shortest path problem",
        "An o(n log n) sorting network",
        "Parallel approximate undirected shortest paths via low hop emulators",
        "Fully dynamic (2 + epsilon) approximate all-pairs shortest paths with fast query and close to linear update time",
        "Approximate undirected transshipment and shortest paths via gradient descent",
        "Improved dynamic algorithms for maintaining approximate shortest paths under deletions",
        "Efficient NC algorithms for set cover with applications to learning and geometry",
        "Polylog-time and near-linear work approximation scheme for undirected shortest paths",
        "Using selective path-doubling for parallel shortest-path computations",
        "Matrix multiplication via arithmetic progressions",
        "Almost shortest paths and PRAM distance oracles in weighted graphs",
        "Near-additive spanners in low polynomial deterministic CONGEST time",
        "Efficient algorithms for constructing very sparse spanners and emulators",
        "Linear-size hopsets with small hopbound, and distributed routing with low memory",
        "Near-optimal distributed routing with low memory",
        "Hopsets with constant hopbound, and applications to approximate shortest paths",
        "Centralized and parallel multi-source shortest paths via hopsets and fast matrix multiplication",
        "(1+epsilon, beta)-spanner constructions for general graphs",
        "All pairs shortest paths for graphs with small integer length edges",
        "Parallel symmetry-breaking in sparse graphs",
        "Improved rectangular matrix multiplication using powers of the coppersmith-winograd tensor",
        "A deterministic almost-tight distributed algorithm for approximating single-source shortest paths",
        "Thorup-zwick emulators are universally optimal hopsets",
        "An Introduction to Parallel Algorithms",
        "Deterministic distributed ruling sets of line graphs",
        "A time-randomness tradeoff",
        "Randomized algorithms and pseudorandom numbers",
        "Parallel algorithms for shared-memory machines",
        "A parallel randomized approximation scheme for shortest paths",
        "A randomized parallel algorithm for single-source shortest paths",
        "A fast parallel algorithm for the maximal independent set problem",
        "Faster parallel algorithm for approximate shortest path",
        "A simple parallel algorithm for the maximal independent set problem",
        "Navigating central path with electrical flows: From flows to matchings, and back",
        "Small-bias probability spaces: Efficient constructions and applications",
        "Hardness vs. randomness (extended abstract)",
        "Symmetry breaking depending on the chromatic number or the neighborhood growth",
        "Generalized preconditioning and network flow problems",
        "Time-work tradeoffs for parallel algorithms",
        "Time-work tradeoffs of the single-source shortest paths problem",
        "An o(log n) parallel connectivity algorithm",
        "Compact routing schemes",
        "Spanners and emulators with sublinear distance errors",
        "High-probability parallel transitive-closure algorithms",
        "Multiplying matrices faster than coppersmith-winograd",
        "All pairs shortest paths in weighted directed graphs-exact and almost exact algorithms",
        "All pairs shortest paths using bridging sets and rectangular matrix multiplication"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 50 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Deterministic PRAM Approximate Shortest Paths in Polylogarithmic Time and Slightly Super-Linear Work, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
